description.narrative: (i) Job Creation: IFC experience has shown that small to midcap companies can achieve higher job creation rates than large cap companies. IFC would support job creation in Russia since Elbrus' midcap growth strategy is in full alignment with IFC's development impact goals. (ii) Access to Finance: Long-term equity/risk capital is limited in Russia. SMEs usually access short term bank loans in the absence of equity investors. The shortage of capital from independent global investors, unrelated to local political groups is very pronounced. Russia has the lowest private equity penetration when compared to other BRIC countries. IFC's investment would support Russian companies by providing additional equity to the small /midcap market. (iii) Private Sector Development: Elbrus will employ hands on management as well as buy and build value added strategy in portfolio companies. The Fund's structuring know-how and network would be tapped, and new management techniques and growth strategies would be incorporated by investee companies; leading to improved competitiveness and sustainability. (iv) The Fund will consider making investments in companies outside Moscow and St. Petersburg where SMEs are often underserved for equity capital.

The proposed project is to make an equity investment of up to USD 20 million to Elbrus Capital Fund II LP (the Fund), a closed-end private equity fund which will make investments in mid-sized private Russian enterprises. The Fund will be domiciled in Cayman Islands. Target size is USD 500 million; Manager aims to invest USD 20-50 million per investment for a controlling equity stake in companies with an enterprise value of USD 50-150 million.
